answers.answer: So now I have an additional question.  My knees tend to get stuck, like they sublocate when I'm lying down, and I change position.  Last week I ended up going by ambulance to the ER because I couldn't get my left knee  back in place.  After the doctor got it back in place, he told me he thought I had a torn miniscus, gave me a brace, and referred me to an orthopedist.  Even though I told the orthopedist that this happens with both knees, and his evaluation showed that there was some catching in both knees, he sent me for an MRI on the left knee.  Three days later, the right knee got stuck, but I managed to get it back in place on my own.  So,  my additional question is could this also be related to neuromuscular disease?    I feel like my whole body is falling apart, but the food allergies issue and the knees are the two things I can not attribute to Autonomic Neuropathy, if that is indeed my diagnoses, or can I?

question: I have a tentative diagnoses of Autonomic Neuropathy, without diabetes.  Recently I have experienced a typical allergic response when I ate tree nuts. (burning sensation in mouth)  A few days later, I had a similar reaction when I ate some cheese from a ball that was covered in almond slices with the same burning sensation in my mouth and vomiting.  The next few days I noticed that tomatoes and raspberries gave me the same burning feeling in my mouth.  My question is, am I more likely to experience food allergies if I have neuromuscular disease?  It seems strange that this should happen at age 51 with foods I have been eating all my life.
title: Food allergies and Autonomic Neuropathy
